description: From Middle English blaunchen, from Old French blanchir, from Old French blanc (“white”), from early Medieval Latin blancus, from Frankish *blank, from Proto-Germanic *blankaz (“bright, shining, blinding, white”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleyǵ- (“to shine”).

verbs.description: blanch (third-person singular simple present blanches, present participle blanching, simple past and past participle blanched)

examples: The rose blanches in the sun.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take the color out of, and make white; to bleach.
(transitive, cooking) To cook by dipping briefly into boiling water, then directly into cold water.
(transitive) To whiten, for example the surface of meat, by plunging into boiling water and afterwards into cold, so as to harden the surface and retain the juices
(transitive) To bleach by excluding the light, for example the stalks or leaves of plants, by earthing them up or tying them together
(transitive) To make white by removing the skin of, for example by scalding
(transitive) To give a white lustre to (silver, before stamping, in the process of coining)
(intransitive) To cover (sheet iron) with a coating of tin.
(transitive, figuratively) To give a favorable appearance to; to whitewash; to whiten;

description: Variant of blench, of same Proto-Indo-European origin.

verbs.description: blanch (third-person singular simple present blanches, present participle blanching, simple past and past participle blanched)

entries.meaning: To avoid, as from fear; to evade; to leave unnoticed.
examples: Ifs and ands to qualify words of treason; whereby every man might express his malice, and blanch his danger.

entries.meaning: To cause to turn aside or back.
